section.title: Running commands with administrative rights
section.para: When working on the command line, any command can be run as an administrator by prefixing the command with sudo. Sudo will remember your password for 15 minutes to allow you to perform multiple administrative tasks without being prompted for a password each time.

note.para: If the program you wish to run as an administrator is graphical, such as the Leafpad text editor, you should use the command gksudo instead of sudo, even if you are running the application from the command line.

warning.para: Be careful when using sudo; you might damage your system if you type the wrong command! As a general rule, only use sudo when absolutely necessary. When you use sudo from a terminal, be sure to close it when you have finished!

section.para: For more information on sudo, see the sudo page on the Ubuntu community wiki.
